attributes.title: Central Children in Social Media Networks: Do They Influence Peers in a Positive Way?
attributes.description: This is the pre-registration for the formal analysis part. The methods described in this registration were developed and tested using the exploratory data set (Wave 4), and we plan to apply them to the formal data set (Wave 5-7). In this registration, we will describe the procedures of data cleaning, analyzing, model building, inference making.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
Central Children in Social Media Networks: Do They Influence Peers in a Positive Way? 
- Data analysis method for the formal analysis

other.value: Our flow charts for the data cleaning process and our R codes for the exploratory analysis of wave 4, will be stored in the OSF repository of this project (https://osf.io/g2ep5/). The formal analysis will be done on the data gathered from 3 waves (w5, w6, w7). Therefore, the standardization within waves and the variable "wave" in the multilevel model will be added. For other analyses, we expect to use the same scripts for the formal analysis as the exploratory analysis. If however, we encounter new situations where we have good reason to make changes to the script, these changes will be registered as well.

sample.value: The data were already collected. Therefore, all the data we have will be used in this study. The number of participants is 774, and 518 out of them sent at least one message in the social media (van Woudenberg et. al., 2020). The actual number of participants in our analysis could be larger than 518 because it is possible that some children only sent likes but no messages.

analyses.value:
Mixed-effects models will be used to examine the hypothesis. The models will be constructed in the Bayesian way using brms package in R. The strength of evidence will be inferred from Bayes factors, which is computed using BayesRS package in R. Four different models will be constructed, with each of the four centrality measures as the fixed effect. A random intercept for participants and waves and the random slope for waves will be included in every model to address the clustered structure of the data (i.e., the contents are nested in participants and waves). Besides, the scale suggested by Jeffrey (1961) will be used to help to interpret the strength of the evidence corresponding to the Bayes factors. 
If any technical problems occur in our formal analysis, we will move to Bayesian analysis based on the BayesFactor package. If that doesn't work either, we will go back to use a frequentist approach with Satterthwaite correction to draw the conclusions, which is implemented in the afex package.

outliers.value: Participants are excluded from corresponding models if their centrality measurement cannot be calculated. This may come from the following reasons: the participant only sent group messages but no one-to-one messages or likes, so he/she cannot be included in the network; the participant is the only one who sent messages or likes in his/her classroom, therefore the SD is 0 and standardized score cannot be calculated.

dependent.value:
Positivity of communication. 
The messages sent by the participants will be analyzed by a sentiment analysis package, the Dutch version of pattern (Smedt & Daelemans, 2012). The package will give a positivity score for each message, which would be used in this project as an indicator of the positivity of youths’ online communication.
Real-life messages sent by the children contain many spelling errors. Therefore, before analyzing the content, we will clean the raw data. Our approach is based on the automatic correction package hunspell. Basically, we make manual dictionaries for the frequently occurring words that hunspell couldn't give correct suggestions, and use them to replace the words in the original content. The words that are not corrected by our manual corrections will be handled by hunspell. If hunspell isn't able to correct them, they will be replaced by "\\\\". The process of data cleaning is also described with more details in the flowcharts and the codes in this repository. For the formal analysis, the communication data of the waves 5-7 will first be checked to determine whether the manual correction list needs to be updated. If the frequency of new unrecognized words is more than 9, we will update the manual corrections list accordingly.

conditions.value:
There were no experimental conditions in this study.
The independent variables are 4 centrality measures: indegree centrality message, indegree centrality likes, outdegree centrality message, outdegree centrality likes. 
Network analyses will be used to calculate the centrality of each person. The social networks will be based on the online interactions (i.e., messages and likes) of the participants. Every interaction will be an edge in the network. The indegree centrality will be measured as the number of ties that are directed towards the node (messages and likes received). Whereas outdegree centrality will be measured as the number of ties that the node directs to others (likes and messages send). Those indicators will be standardized within each classroom and each wave, because the participants in some classrooms used the social network more often than those in other classrooms, and some participants dropped out after some waves.

hypothesis.value: We hypothesize that the central children in social media networks communicate more negatively than less central counterparts.

attributes.title: Objective norms, fear, and wellbeing in the Covid-19 situation
attributes.description: This project will estimate the total effect on subjective wellbeing  of objective norms of Covid-protective behaviors on happiness and the extent to which these are direct or indirect through fear of Covid-19. Personal efficacy and Education will be controlled.

q2.value:
The hypotheses concern regression coefficients in these models:
Model 1 (total effect): E(Wellbeing)= β0 + β1ObjectiveNorm + β2SelfEfficacy +...BkXk

Model 2 (direct effect): E(Wellbeing)= C0 + C1ObjectiveNorm + C2SelfEfficacy + C3Fear+ ... + Ck+1Xk+1

Model 3: indirect chain: E(Fear)= D0 + D1ObjectiveNorm + D2SelfEfficacy +  ... + CkXk
The indirect effect is calculated as total effect-direct effect, i.e.  β1-C1

Hypothesis 1: β1>0

Hypothesis 2: C1<0

Hypothesis 3: D1<0

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Paper 1
The data for Paper 1 are the cases from the International Social Science Survey, Round 21's frequent contact panel survey for respondents taking the debut survey in April 16-21, 2020. This is an internet panel. Respondents are drawn primarily from MTurk, but the survey also invites respondents to invite friends and relatives they think may be interested to take the survey (different sources are retained as a variable to be included in the analysis to control for clustering).
The questions to be analyzed include the following.
(1) The dependent/response variable is the WHO-5 Well-Being Index containing items pretested by the WHO and widely used (World Health Organization 1998). It is a short and generic global rating scale measuring subjective well-being. After checking scale properties, it will be used as a simple additive scale in the regression analysis.
(2) The focal predictor/independent variable is "Objective Norms" or ONCPB (Scale of objective norms on Covid-19 protective behaviors). The items concern the Covid-19 protective behavior of other people Rs are likely to observe in their immediate vicinity: "neighbors", "people at your workplace", "other shoppers in your usual grocery store", and "cashiers in grocery stores".  The items follow detailed questions about how you personally engage in a list of Covid-protective behaviors, how efficacious you think each one is, and whether each is/ would be emotionally costly to you, so when Rs are asked about how often these sets of actors engage in Covid-protective behaviors, the usual set of these will be salient. These will be included in a simple additive scale to make our focal predictor variable in the regression analysis. This scale is new in these data, so there are no prior reports on its psychometric properties.
(3) Fear is a simple additive 3-item scale measuring how afraid R is of Covid-19. It is one of the predictors. This scale is new in these data, so there are no prior reports on its psychometric properties.
(4) Control variables to be included are education (in years) and self-efficacy, AKA personal efficacy or agency, closely akin to internal locus of control (Bandura 2011). Education is a single item measured in year of education completed and self-efficacy is a 3-item scale adapted to the epidemic situation. This scale is new in these data, so there are no prior reports on its psychometric properties.
Subsequent papers
I anticipate that other kindred measures would lead to substantively similar results.
References
Bandura, Albert. 2011. "Social Cognitive Theory." in Handbook of Theories of Social Psychology, edited by A. W. K. Paul A. M. Van Lange, E. Tory Higgins. Beverly Hills: Sage.
World Health Organization. 1998. "Wellbeing Measures in Primary Health Care/the Depcare Project." Vol.  Copenhagen: WHO Regional Office for Europe.

q18.value: Original items will be mapped onto equal intervals over the range 0 to 100. Scales will be computed as the means of their component items for which R has valid data.

q20.value: The data here come from closed-ended questions so there will be no gross data entry errors.  No data points will be excluded

q21.value: For the scales/ indices, I will use the mean of the items with valid codes. If R is missing on all the items, they will be excluded from analysis. For sensitivity tests in the papers subsequent to Paper 1, we will examine whether imputation of missing data changes the results.

q15.value: [Note: This preregistration is an updated version of our preregistration for EGAP study 20160507AA. We are conducting a replication study. We note deviations from the original design below but the preregistrations are otherwise identical.] Fact-checking is an increasingly popular way for American political journalists to verify the accuracy of statements by political figures. The trend has grown rapidly, with prominent organizations such as FactCheck.org and PolitiFact receiving national recognition and journalism awards. The work of fact-checking organizations is often cited in the media, giving credibility and professional acceptance to this new form of political coverage. There is currently very little literature on the effects of fact-checking. Moreover, existing research on the effects of correcting misperceptions has generated conflicting results. Nyhan and Reifler (2010) found that corrections failed to reduce misperceptions and, in some extreme cases produced a “backfire effect” in which corrections strengthened misperceptions. Fridkin et al. (2015) showed that fact-checks of negative television advertisements influenced people’s assessments of the accuracy, usefulness, and tone of negative political advertisements. Finally, Nyhan and Reifler (2016) showed that there was no evidence that exposure to fact-checking affected people’s attitudes toward the practice, trust in politicians, or feelings of political efficacy, but exposure to fact-checking did increase how much people knew about contemporary political controversies and debates. The specific objective of this project is to examine the effects of summary fact-checking, an innovation in the field that is becoming more common. This format presents an overview of ratings of the accuracy of a politician’s statements rather than an evaluation of a single statement. Our study will measure the effects of summary fact-checks on a politician’s perceived accuracy and favorability. This project will also compare the effects of summary fact-checks to individual fact-checks that only verify a singular statement. We expect that summary fact-checking will be seen as more comprehensive and less selective than individual fact-checks and may therefore have a greater effect on public perceptions of politicians. Our experiment will therefore assess whether or not the effect of individual fact-checks differs from the effect of summary fact-checks on an individual’s favorability toward a politician or the perceived accuracy of their statements. We will also take the political affiliation of both the participant and the politician into account, so we can determine whether the effects of individual and summary fact-checks vary by whether the target is a co-partisan or an opposition partisan. Finally, we will also consider whether these effects vary by political knowledge and analyze whether exposure to summary or individual fact-checks affects attitudes toward the practice more generally. The results of this experiment will allow us to understand the efficacy of different forms of fact-checking, which may help us better understand how news outlets’ fact-checking practices influence public opinion. This replication experiment modifies the summary fact-checking treatment to omit any comparison between the senator in question and the average senator. Minor modifications were also made to correct typographical errors and to update the content of the survey to be accurate for administration in November 2016. (The first study was administered in May 2016.)

In general, how favorable or unfavorable is your overall opinion of the fact-checking movement in journalism? -Very favorable (6) -Somewhat favorable (5) -Slightly favorable (4) -Slightly unfavorable (3) -Somewhat unfavorable (2) -Very unfavorable (1) Thinking about the amount of fact-checking that you see being performed today by journalists, do you think there should be more fact-checking, the current amount of fact-checking is about right, or there should be less fact-checking? -There should be more fact-checking. (3) -The current amount of fact-checking is about right. (2) -There should be less fact-checking. (1) In general, how often do you think articles published by fact-checkers are accurate? -All of the time (5) -Most of the time (4) -About half the time (3) -Occasionally (2) -Never (1) In presenting the news dealing with political and social issues, do you think fact-checkers deal fairly with all sides or tend to favor one side? -Fact-checkers tend to deal fairly with all sides. (1) -Fact-checkers tend to favor one side. (0) Statistical analyses For each of our analyses, we will use OLS with robust standard errors and estimate ordered probit models with robust standard errors as a robustness check. Unless otherwise noted, all experimental treatment effects will be estimated as intent to treat effects. Leaners will be treated as partisans in our statistical analyses. Perceptions of politicians will only be assessed for the first politician for which outcome measures were collected to avoid contrast effects. Participants’ political knowledge will be assessed with a standard five-question battery that test participant knowledge of U.S. electoral rules and awareness of current political figures. Partisanship is measured on a standard seven-point scale administered via branching questions. Our primary model will be pooled regressions for individuals who saw either candidate, but we will also estimate regressions interacting target politician with fact-checking type (the main explanatory variable). If we cannot reject the null of no difference in effects by target, we will present the pooled model and also present separate results for Reid and McConnell either in the main text or an appendix. If the effects of key explanatory variables differ depending on the fact-checking target, we will present separate models for Reid and McConnell in the main text for expositional clarity and present interactive models in an appendix. We will estimate marginal effects as appropriate when interaction terms are included in our models. (We will also estimate our treatment effect models with standard demographic controls and report these results if the treatment effect estimate is substantively different from the model only including partisan affiliation.) To test H1, we will estimate the model y=b0+b1*summaryFC+b2*individualFC for the accuracy and favorability outcome measures. To test H2, we will then evaluate b1-b2 directly for each outcome measure. To test H3, we will estimate the model y=b0+b1*summaryFC+b2*individualFC+b3*copartisan+b4*opposition+b5*summaryFCXcopartisan+b6*summaryFCXopposition+b7*individualFCXcopartisan+b8*individualFCXopposition and then estimate b5-b6 and b7-b8. [Per above, we will estimate all pairwise comparisons in treatment effects between partisan groups. However, we expect to encounter power problems given the relatively small number of pure independents and may thus focus on the comparison between the co-partisan and opposition partisan groups.] To test RQ1, we will first estimate the model y=b0+b1*summaryFC+b2*individualFC+b3*knowledge+ b4*summaryFCXknowledge+b5*individualFCXknowledge and then estimate y=b0+b1*summaryFC+b2*individualFC+b3*copartisan+b4*opposition+b5*summaryFCXcopartisan+b6*summaryFCXopposition+b7*individualFCXcopartisan+b8*individualFCXopposition +b9*knowledge+b10*summaryFCXknowledge+b11*individualFCXknowledge+b12*copartisanXknowledge+b13*oppositionXknowledge+b14*summaryFCXknowledgeXopposition+b15*individualFCXknowledgeXopposition. In each model, we will estimate whether the effects of the fact-checks vary by political knowledge versus the control group and each other (and, in the latter case, by partisanship as well). We will test whether the effect of knowledge is linear per Hainmueller et al. and follow their recommendations if not. We may also present a simple median split on knowledge in the main text and report the continuous interaction model in the appendix for expositional clarity. We will follow the same procedures for education, grouping all the some college/associate groups together in the continuous measure and treating college/non-college as the relevant binary measure. To test RQ2, we will estimate the model y=b0+b1*summaryFC+b2*individualFC for individual fact-check opinion measures and the composite fact-check opinion measure (if they scale together) and then estimate b1-b2.

registration_responses.q15: [Note: This preregistration is an updated version of our preregistration for EGAP study 20160507AA. We are conducting a replication study. We note deviations from the original design below but the preregistrations are otherwise identical.] Fact-checking is an increasingly popular way for American political journalists to verify the accuracy of statements by political figures. The trend has grown rapidly, with prominent organizations such as FactCheck.org and PolitiFact receiving national recognition and journalism awards. The work of fact-checking organizations is often cited in the media, giving credibility and professional acceptance to this new form of political coverage. There is currently very little literature on the effects of fact-checking. Moreover, existing research on the effects of correcting misperceptions has generated conflicting results. Nyhan and Reifler (2010) found that corrections failed to reduce misperceptions and, in some extreme cases produced a “backfire effect” in which corrections strengthened misperceptions. Fridkin et al. (2015) showed that fact-checks of negative television advertisements influenced people’s assessments of the accuracy, usefulness, and tone of negative political advertisements. Finally, Nyhan and Reifler (2016) showed that there was no evidence that exposure to fact-checking affected people’s attitudes toward the practice, trust in politicians, or feelings of political efficacy, but exposure to fact-checking did increase how much people knew about contemporary political controversies and debates. The specific objective of this project is to examine the effects of summary fact-checking, an innovation in the field that is becoming more common. This format presents an overview of ratings of the accuracy of a politician’s statements rather than an evaluation of a single statement. Our study will measure the effects of summary fact-checks on a politician’s perceived accuracy and favorability. This project will also compare the effects of summary fact-checks to individual fact-checks that only verify a singular statement. We expect that summary fact-checking will be seen as more comprehensive and less selective than individual fact-checks and may therefore have a greater effect on public perceptions of politicians. Our experiment will therefore assess whether or not the effect of individual fact-checks differs from the effect of summary fact-checks on an individual’s favorability toward a politician or the perceived accuracy of their statements. We will also take the political affiliation of both the participant and the politician into account, so we can determine whether the effects of individual and summary fact-checks vary by whether the target is a co-partisan or an opposition partisan. Finally, we will also consider whether these effects vary by political knowledge and analyze whether exposure to summary or individual fact-checks affects attitudes toward the practice more generally. The results of this experiment will allow us to understand the efficacy of different forms of fact-checking, which may help us better understand how news outlets’ fact-checking practices influence public opinion. This replication experiment modifies the summary fact-checking treatment to omit any comparison between the senator in question and the average senator. Minor modifications were also made to correct typographical errors and to update the content of the survey to be accurate for administration in November 2016. (The first study was administered in May 2016.)

attributes.title: Family adjustment and coping
attributes.description: This is a prospective longitudinal study to understand children's and family's adjustment in the US following COVID-19 pandemic.

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1: Three to five trajectory profiles would emerge from based multi-trajectory modeling based upon past research with adolescents and adult samples (e.g., Bonanno et al., 2010; Weems & Graham, 2013). 

Hypothesis 1A: One group would emerge with consistent low symptoms across all four domains assessed. One group would emerge as increasing symptoms or persistent high symptoms. One group would emerge with increasing and then decreasing symptoms. 

Hypothesis 1B: Older child age and female child gender would be associated with at-risk profiles.

Hypothesis 2: “Resilient” groups, as compared to “at-risk” groups from the group-based multi-trajectory modeling, would be associated with lower parental depressive and anxiety symptoms, higher parental warmth, lower parental overprotection, more social support, less financial distress, and reduced media exposure. 

Hypothesis 3: Parenting behaviors would mediate and/or moderate the relationship between parental mental health and child symptoms.  

Hypothesis 4: Qualitative findings would converge with quantitative findings, as well as offer in-depth information about unique family characteristics related to post-disaster adjustments, such as raising children with disabilities or experiences of racism among ethnic-racial minority families.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a prospective, short-term longitudinal design with a mixed-method approach. Participants will provide three survey responses across roughly four months, with a subsample of participants further selected for interview follow-ups.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Target population. Participants will be primary caregivers who have one child between the age of 3- to 8- years old. This specific age range allows us to both focus on children (as compared to adolescents and adults) and examine the potential age effect. Due to the vast cross-national differences in impact from and responses to COVID-19, we limit the target population to be primary caregivers currently residing in the United States. 

Procedure. Participants will be recruited from social media platforms and social service agencies. To account for geographic heterogeneity within the United States, we plan to contact social service agencies that primarily serve children, parents, and families across all regions (i.e., Northeast, Midwest, South, West). This heterogeneity will be cross-checked with participants’ self-reported state and postcode information.  We will also match geolocation with the COVID-19 cases and deaths data repository (https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-data) to investigate if local COVID-19 severity is associated with adjustment profiles.

Upon consent, participants will provide a valid email address for this longitudinal project. Participants will be asked to fill out three online surveys with a two-month interval between each of the surveys. Each survey will take about 10 to 15 minutes to complete and questions will be prompted to focus on one target child between 3 to 8 years identified in the initial survey. A selected group of participants (around 20) will be contacted after the completion of the surveys for a semi-structured interview (~1 hour). In terms of study incentives, participants will be entered into a drawing, to protect online data collection integrity, after completion of the first survey. Participants will be provided a 7-dollar gift card after completion of each follow-up survey, to account for natural attrition in the longitudinal study as well as potentially heightened barriers following COVID-19.

q11.value: An estimated 400 primary caregivers are expected to participate in the study.

q12.value: The sample size was selected in order to account for attribution (estimated up to 50%) in longitudinal study design as well as power for accurate parameter estimation in a latent growth mixture model (Nylund et al., 2007).

question.value: NA

Children’s adjustment will be assessed each wave with the Pediatric Emotional Distress Scale (PEDS; Saylor et al., 1999), a well-validated and used tool to screen symptoms in two- to ten- year old children after experiencing traumatic events. PEDS includes four dimensions: anxious/withdrawal symptoms (6 items; e.g., “cries without good reason”), fearfulness (5 items; e.g., “refuses to go to sleep alone”), acting out (6 items; e.g., “acts aggressively”), and trauma-specific responses (4 items; e.g., “brings up coronavirus in conversation”). Other parent-reported child behaviors to be assessed include child daily screen usage time and screen usage purposes.

Parental distress will be assessed by Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item Scale (GAD-7; Spitzer et al., 2006) and Kessler Screening Scale for Psychological Distress (K6; Kessler et al., 2002), as trauma psychologists have argued for measuring broader psychological functioning beyond PTSD symptoms (e.g., Bonanno et al., 2010). Multidimensional Assessment of Parenting Scale (MAPS; Parent & Forehand, 2017) will assess positive domain (e.g., proactive parenting, positive reinforcement, warmth, and supportiveness) and negative domain (i.e., hostility, physical control, and lax control) with a total of 34 items. A set of questions related to parent communication about COVID-19 will also be included for the current project, including an open-ended narrative question asking parents to describe the details of a recent conversation they have with their children. 

Demographic information about parents (e.g., marital status, highest educational attainment, etc.), children (e.g., age, gender, disability status, etc.), and family (e.g., annual income, geographic location, significant losses/deaths, etc.) will be gathered. InCharge Financial Distress/Well-being Scale (Prawitz et al., 2006) will assess the family’s current financial well-being and distress (10 items; e.g., “how stressed do you feel about your personal finances?”). The family financial adjustment scale (Danes & Rettig, 1995) will be adapted to assess the financial decisions families made during COVID-19 (15 items; e.g., “borrowed money to help pay bills”).

Lastly, the PI and his team will conduct semi-structured interviews with at least 4 families from each adjustment trajectory profile to capture the nuances built upon the overarching picture from the survey data. In keeping with best practices for qualitative research, the final sample of interviewees will be based on thematic saturation (Bowen, 2008). Interviews will gather data on the four main study topics, including: (1) How do they perceive their children’s’ adjustment following COVID-19; (2) How do they perceive their own adjustment following COVID-19; (3) How would they describe their parenting approaches before and after COVID-19 outbreak; (4) What salient factors impacted their family’s adjustment following COVID-19.

Preliminary Analysis. We will collect de-identified participant recruitment data via online survey logs, including (1) attrition and completion at each wave, (2) attention check questions, and (3) time spent to complete each survey. This information will be used to ensure data integrity from a social media convenience sample. We will inspect distributions, univariate and multivariate normality, covariance structures, as well as joint distributional properties of each ER and substance use outcome variable. Where possible, we will develop latent construct measures for these outcomes to maximize the multi-source, multi-method data, avoid inflation of Type I error due to multiple comparisons, and increase measurement reliability (Messick, 1989). Our criteria for including an indicator in a latent construct are as follows: the items comprising the indicator must show internal consistency (α ≥ .60; item-total correlation ≥ .20) and the scale or indicator convergence in a CFA structural equation model (SEM) must demonstrate acceptable fit criteria.   

Group-based multi-trajectory modeling. To identify whether children reported varying symptom trajectories, we utilized group-based multi-trajectory modeling (Nagin et al., 2018) in SAS. Group-based multi-trajectory modeling is an extension of the univariate Growth Mixture Modeling (GMM). Group-based multi-trajectory modeling allows the identification of different profiles by the joint development of four symptom areas: anxious/withdrawal symptoms, fearfulness, acting out, and trauma-specific responses. A conditional model will also be estimated using county-level confirmed and death data as covariates to see if it increases the model fit. Extent data suggested a direct relationship between overall death toll and individual-level psychopathology among samples.

Parameters will be estimated using maximum likelihood estimation through a Newton-Raphson optimization algorithm and censored-normal models. Model selection of the number of groups and polynomial order (first or second) of the trajectories was based on a larger Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), the average posterior probability of assignment (APPA) above .70, the odds of correct classification (OCC) above 5.0, a smaller mismatch between estimated and assigned group probabilities, a smaller standard deviation of group membership probabilities (SD-GMP), and the percentage of individuals estimated to be assigned to the smallest group above 1% (Klijn et al., 2017). Each child will be assigned to the multi-trajectory group having the highest posterior probability.

After the selection of the final model, protective and risk factors will be examined for differences across the trajectory groups by analysis of variance and chi-square tests. For continuous variables, the mean parameters will be estimated for each group. For categorical variables. the probabilities for each category will be estimated for each group. Pairwise group comparisons after establishing the overall significance of ANOVA and Chi-Square tests will then be computed. The Benjamin-Hochberg procedure was used to adjust for the false discovery rate from multiple comparison rate, which controls the expected proportion of false discoveries (q) amongst the rejected null hypotheses. The false-positive rate was set at q = 0.05.

Moderation and mediation analysis. To further cross-validate our findings above on protective and risk factors, selected parenting and parental mental health constructs will be examined in moderation and mediation structural equation models. Specifically, we will examine how parenting behaviors (i.e., parental communications, warmth, behavioral control) will moderate vs. mediate the relationship between parental mental health and child mental health.  

Qualitative analysis. To supplement the quantitative findings and add depth to the analysis, we will analyze qualitative data derived from both the open-ended survey questions as well as interviews via NVivo 11. Audio-recorded interview data will be transcribed verbatim, cross-checked with the recording for accuracy. We will follow Braun and Clarke's (2006) thematic analysis methods, which is a flexible approach that can be either data- or theory-driven (Vaismoradi et al., 2013). For the proposed project, we will search for salient themes and codes from participants’ responses, and how they may differ across different profiles of child adjustment trajectory.

registration_responses.q6.question: This is a prospective, short-term longitudinal design with a mixed-method approach. Participants will provide three survey responses across roughly four months, with a subsample of participants further selected for interview follow-ups.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Target population. Participants will be primary caregivers who have one child between the age of 3- to 8- years old. This specific age range allows us to both focus on children (as compared to adolescents and adults) and examine the potential age effect. Due to the vast cross-national differences in impact from and responses to COVID-19, we limit the target population to be primary caregivers currently residing in the United States. 

Procedure. Participants will be recruited from social media platforms and social service agencies. To account for geographic heterogeneity within the United States, we plan to contact social service agencies that primarily serve children, parents, and families across all regions (i.e., Northeast, Midwest, South, West). This heterogeneity will be cross-checked with participants’ self-reported state and postcode information.  We will also match geolocation with the COVID-19 cases and deaths data repository (https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-data) to investigate if local COVID-19 severity is associated with adjustment profiles.

Upon consent, participants will provide a valid email address for this longitudinal project. Participants will be asked to fill out three online surveys with a two-month interval between each of the surveys. Each survey will take about 10 to 15 minutes to complete and questions will be prompted to focus on one target child between 3 to 8 years identified in the initial survey. A selected group of participants (around 20) will be contacted after the completion of the surveys for a semi-structured interview (~1 hour). In terms of study incentives, participants will be entered into a drawing, to protect online data collection integrity, after completion of the first survey. Participants will be provided a 7-dollar gift card after completion of each follow-up survey, to account for natural attrition in the longitudinal study as well as potentially heightened barriers following COVID-19.
registration_responses.q14.question: NA
registration_responses.q15.question:
Children’s adjustment will be assessed each wave with the Pediatric Emotional Distress Scale (PEDS; Saylor et al., 1999), a well-validated and used tool to screen symptoms in two- to ten- year old children after experiencing traumatic events. PEDS includes four dimensions: anxious/withdrawal symptoms (6 items; e.g., “cries without good reason”), fearfulness (5 items; e.g., “refuses to go to sleep alone”), acting out (6 items; e.g., “acts aggressively”), and trauma-specific responses (4 items; e.g., “brings up coronavirus in conversation”). Other parent-reported child behaviors to be assessed include child daily screen usage time and screen usage purposes.

Parental distress will be assessed by Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item Scale (GAD-7; Spitzer et al., 2006) and Kessler Screening Scale for Psychological Distress (K6; Kessler et al., 2002), as trauma psychologists have argued for measuring broader psychological functioning beyond PTSD symptoms (e.g., Bonanno et al., 2010). Multidimensional Assessment of Parenting Scale (MAPS; Parent & Forehand, 2017) will assess positive domain (e.g., proactive parenting, positive reinforcement, warmth, and supportiveness) and negative domain (i.e., hostility, physical control, and lax control) with a total of 34 items. A set of questions related to parent communication about COVID-19 will also be included for the current project, including an open-ended narrative question asking parents to describe the details of a recent conversation they have with their children. 

Demographic information about parents (e.g., marital status, highest educational attainment, etc.), children (e.g., age, gender, disability status, etc.), and family (e.g., annual income, geographic location, significant losses/deaths, etc.) will be gathered. InCharge Financial Distress/Well-being Scale (Prawitz et al., 2006) will assess the family’s current financial well-being and distress (10 items; e.g., “how stressed do you feel about your personal finances?”). The family financial adjustment scale (Danes & Rettig, 1995) will be adapted to assess the financial decisions families made during COVID-19 (15 items; e.g., “borrowed money to help pay bills”).

Lastly, the PI and his team will conduct semi-structured interviews with at least 4 families from each adjustment trajectory profile to capture the nuances built upon the overarching picture from the survey data. In keeping with best practices for qualitative research, the final sample of interviewees will be based on thematic saturation (Bowen, 2008). Interviews will gather data on the four main study topics, including: (1) How do they perceive their children’s’ adjustment following COVID-19; (2) How do they perceive their own adjustment following COVID-19; (3) How would they describe their parenting approaches before and after COVID-19 outbreak; (4) What salient factors impacted their family’s adjustment following COVID-19.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Preliminary Analysis. We will collect de-identified participant recruitment data via online survey logs, including (1) attrition and completion at each wave, (2) attention check questions, and (3) time spent to complete each survey. This information will be used to ensure data integrity from a social media convenience sample. We will inspect distributions, univariate and multivariate normality, covariance structures, as well as joint distributional properties of each ER and substance use outcome variable. Where possible, we will develop latent construct measures for these outcomes to maximize the multi-source, multi-method data, avoid inflation of Type I error due to multiple comparisons, and increase measurement reliability (Messick, 1989). Our criteria for including an indicator in a latent construct are as follows: the items comprising the indicator must show internal consistency (α ≥ .60; item-total correlation ≥ .20) and the scale or indicator convergence in a CFA structural equation model (SEM) must demonstrate acceptable fit criteria.   

Group-based multi-trajectory modeling. To identify whether children reported varying symptom trajectories, we utilized group-based multi-trajectory modeling (Nagin et al., 2018) in SAS. Group-based multi-trajectory modeling is an extension of the univariate Growth Mixture Modeling (GMM). Group-based multi-trajectory modeling allows the identification of different profiles by the joint development of four symptom areas: anxious/withdrawal symptoms, fearfulness, acting out, and trauma-specific responses. A conditional model will also be estimated using county-level confirmed and death data as covariates to see if it increases the model fit. Extent data suggested a direct relationship between overall death toll and individual-level psychopathology among samples.

Parameters will be estimated using maximum likelihood estimation through a Newton-Raphson optimization algorithm and censored-normal models. Model selection of the number of groups and polynomial order (first or second) of the trajectories was based on a larger Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), the average posterior probability of assignment (APPA) above .70, the odds of correct classification (OCC) above 5.0, a smaller mismatch between estimated and assigned group probabilities, a smaller standard deviation of group membership probabilities (SD-GMP), and the percentage of individuals estimated to be assigned to the smallest group above 1% (Klijn et al., 2017). Each child will be assigned to the multi-trajectory group having the highest posterior probability.

After the selection of the final model, protective and risk factors will be examined for differences across the trajectory groups by analysis of variance and chi-square tests. For continuous variables, the mean parameters will be estimated for each group. For categorical variables. the probabilities for each category will be estimated for each group. Pairwise group comparisons after establishing the overall significance of ANOVA and Chi-Square tests will then be computed. The Benjamin-Hochberg procedure was used to adjust for the false discovery rate from multiple comparison rate, which controls the expected proportion of false discoveries (q) amongst the rejected null hypotheses. The false-positive rate was set at q = 0.05.

Moderation and mediation analysis. To further cross-validate our findings above on protective and risk factors, selected parenting and parental mental health constructs will be examined in moderation and mediation structural equation models. Specifically, we will examine how parenting behaviors (i.e., parental communications, warmth, behavioral control) will moderate vs. mediate the relationship between parental mental health and child mental health.  

Qualitative analysis. To supplement the quantitative findings and add depth to the analysis, we will analyze qualitative data derived from both the open-ended survey questions as well as interviews via NVivo 11. Audio-recorded interview data will be transcribed verbatim, cross-checked with the recording for accuracy. We will follow Braun and Clarke's (2006) thematic analysis methods, which is a flexible approach that can be either data- or theory-driven (Vaismoradi et al., 2013). For the proposed project, we will search for salient themes and codes from participants’ responses, and how they may differ across different profiles of child adjustment trajectory.

attributes.title: Procedural justice and identity: police officers' perceptions compared to civilians
attributes.description:
This study will sample from both police officers and civilians and replicate previous procedural justice research by relying on vignettes in which decision-making process are manipulated through the components of procedural justice. Participants will evaluate the fairness of the decision-making processes in vignettes of police-civilian interactions. The vignettes will expand on previous research on process-based policing by incorporating the police officer violating the Fourth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution and searches the civilian without consent. This manipulation will also serve to examine the role of voice in evaluating police-civilian interactions, especially when constitutional rights are asserted or not. Three pilot studies were conducted to test manipulations of the procedural justice components individually to create the procedural justice and no procedural justice vignettes.
This study will answer the two research questions: through what mechanisms in the procedural justice framework do police officers, as compared to civilians, evaluate fairness in police-civilian interactions and does the extent of overlap between self- and social-identity mitigate the effect of role on evaluations of fairness. We expect to find that evaluations of fairness are predicted by procedural justice condition via indirect effects through the justice subscales for both the police and civilians. However, we expect the indirect effects to be different for police officers than for civilians and for those differences to be explained by a moderating effect of the extent to which the participants identify with the police versus their neighborhood. We expect that police officers who identify more closely with their neighborhood or community than with other police will evaluate fairness through the same mechanisms as civilians. However, police officers who identify more closely with the police than with their community will evaluate fairness through different mechanisms than civilian participants. We expect this moderation because participants both rely on and get identity information from procedural justice in police-civilian encounters (Blader & Tyler, 2009; Leonardielli & Min Toh, 2010; Oliveria & Murphy, 2016).

q1.value: Katherine Pearl Hazen, Eve M. Brank

q2.value:
We expect to find a significant 2 x 2 interaction between vignette condition and sample for most of the subscales (voice, neutrality, trust, respect, global fairness) of the adapted Family Justice Scale such that the mean difference between the procedural justice and no procedural justice conditions will be greater for police officer participants than civilian participants, consistent with our previous findings for voice behavior (Hazen & Brank, 2020). When evaluating a police-civilian interaction as an observer, police officers will be more sensitive to the differences in the conditions because of their training and experience with police-civilian interactions (Hazen & Brank, 2020; Johnson et al., 2018) and because they identify with the police officer in the interaction (Oliviera & Murphy, 2016). Further, experience and feelings toward civilians will be added as covariates in an ANCOVA.  
Next, moderated-mediation analyses will test the relations among the components of procedural justice to understand whether police and civilians evaluate global fairness through the same mechanisms. We hypothesize that the relation between procedural justice condition and evaluations of global fairness would be mediated in a serial, parallel mediation through evaluations of voice, neutrality, trust, and respect. Further, we expect to find that the relation between the procedural justice condition and each modified Family Justice Scale subscale will be moderated by the sample, consistent with previous findings for voice behavior (Hazen & Brank, 2020). The effects will be stronger for police officers than for civilians, replicating the interaction effects described above. This moderation would reveal that police officers interpret the components of procedural justice in police-civilian interactions differently than civilians and provide insight into which components should be examined further to better understand gaps between police officer and civilian interpretations of police-civilian interactions. Additionally, we hypothesize that the extent of identity fusion with the police will moderate the effect of the sample on the effect of the procedural justice condition. We expect that the effect of the sample will be stronger for those who identify more closely with the police than with their neighborhood or family (Oliviera & Murphy, 2016).

question.value: This study will be a 2 (group: police officer, civilians) x 2 (process-based policing: procedural justice, no procedural justice) between-subject quasi-experimental design. The dependent variable will be an adapted version of the global fairness subscale of the Family Justice Scale (Fondacaro et al., 2002). Independent variables will include not only the process-based policing manipulations and the measured group and measured group identity and feelings about both police officers and civilians. Control variables will include attitudes toward police legitimacy, attitudes toward authorities, social dominance orientation, and how they feel about being involved in a traffic stop.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Civilian participants will be recruited through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk and police officer participants will be recruited through the local police departments. Once the participants follow the link to the survey, they will provide informed consent. Next, participants will complete the APLS and the policing experience as well as identity items. Next participants will be instructed to read one randomly assigned vignette and respond to the adapted Family Justice Scale as well as the manipulation checks and identity with the characters. Finally, participants will complete the demographic items.

q11.value: Two-hundred sixty participants, half (n = 130) police officers and half (n = 130) civilians, will be recruited through the local police department and Amazon Mechanical Turk, respectively. A partner at the local police department will send the department officers an email invitation. People from each sample who are interested will follow the link to the survey and complete the survey through Qualtrics. Police officer participants will be compensated $10 and MTurk participants will be compensated $2.50 for their time.

q12.value: Power analyses were conducted with G*Power (Faul et al., 2009) based on the effect size of the mean differences of fairness between the trust (r = .10) and respect (r = .59) conditions in three pilot studies. In order to have a 90% chance of accurately detecting a significant effect of 0.30 (the average effect size) for the mean difference between the procedurally just and unjust conditions, the sample should include 109 total participants, or 54 in each condition (Cohen, 1988). To allow for 10% exclusion for failed manipulation and attention checks and an additional 10% for attrition, the sample should be 65 participants per cell. Therefore, 130 participants will be recruited for each sample, resulting in a total of 260 participants.

question.value:
Process-based policing will have two levels, procedural justice and no procedural justice. 

Participants will read a scenario is based on a police-civilian interaction observed and described by Gould and Mastrofski (2004). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions for the process-based policing manipulation: procedural justice and no procedural justice. The four components of procedural justice will be manipulated in each condition, based on the language used by Mazerolle et al. (2012, 2013) and MacQueen and Bradford (2015) in randomized controlled trials of process-based policing. 

Manipulation checks. Participants will respond to ten yes-or-no questions to evaluate the manipulations; two for each procedural justice component. Three voice manipulation checks will ask “Did John respond to the Officer’s questions,” “Did John consent to be searched by the Officer,” and “Did John engage in voice behavior?” Two neutrality manipulation checks will ask “Did the officer treat John the same as other people on the bike trial,” and “Did the Officer make an impartial decision to stop John?” Two trust manipulation checks will ask “Did the Officer have good intentions toward John,” and “Did the officer explain the department is concerned about overdoses?” Two respect manipulation checks will ask “Did the Officer treat John with respect,” and “Did the officer thank John for his time?” One attention check will also ask “Did the Officer search John’s bag?”

Attitudes toward police. Perceptions of police legitimacy and institutional trust will be measured with the Attitudes Toward Police Legitimacy Scale (APLS; Reynolds, Estrada-Reynolds, & Nunez, 2018) to control for pre-existing attitudes toward the police. The APLS has been found to be a reliable 34-item, single factor scale that measures perceptions of bias (3 items), quality of interpersonal treatment (4 items), trustworthiness (7 items), motivation (5 items), organizational integrity (4 items), being a member of the community (6 items), and normative alignment (4 items) of civilian respondents (Reynolds et al.). Responses will be rated on a 7-point Likert-type agreement scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree), with higher scores indicating more positive attitudes toward police. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with statements such as, “Police officers usually make fair decisions when enforcing laws,” and “Police officers are held to higher standards than regular citizens.”
The Allophilia scale (Alfieri & Marta, 2011; Pittinsky, Rosenthal, & Montoya, 2011) will measure feelings toward police and will be adapted from intergroup bias literature that have been found to be predictive of prejudice and discrimination. Emotions toward the police officers and civilians will be measured with the general dimension scales of the Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS-X) (Watson & Clark, 1999). The two general dimensions scales measure negative affect (e.g., afraid, scared, hostile) and positive affect (e.g., active, alert, excited, proud) with 10 emotions per subscale. Participants will rate the extent to which they felt each emotion when they considered being involved in an involuntary traffic stop (e.g., being stopped by a police officer for speeding, stopping a civilian for speeding) on a 5-point rating-scales (1 = very slightly or not at all; 5 = extremely).
Social dominance orientation (SDO) scale (SDO7) (Ho et al., 2015; Pratto et al., 1994) measures support for inequality between social groups, but not ingroup dominance over outgroups. Participants indicate the extent to which they support 16 items on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly oppose, 7 = strongly favor). SDO7 conceptualizes SDO as comprised of two subdimensions, with half the items on each subscale framed in the positive (pro-traits) and half in the negative (con-traits): the dominance (SDO-D) subdimension and the egalitarianism (SDO-E) subdimension. Con-traits are reversed coded to calculate mean subscale scores for each dimension, with higher scores meaning the participants are more in favor of group dominance. 
SDO-D represents a preference for group-based hierarchies that are created and maintained through active suppression of the subordinate group. SDO-D predicts overt and active efforts by the superordinate group to obtain and maintain dominance, including old-fashioned racism, support for immigrant persecution, support of the death penalty, and support for militarism (Ho et al., 2015). SDO7 includes eight SDO-D items, such as: “Some groups of people must be kept in their place” (pro-trait) and “Groups at the bottom are just as deserving as groups at the top” (con-trait). SDO-E represents opposition to equality between groups through a network of hierarchy-enhancing policies and beliefs. SDO-E predicts system justification, opposition to affirmative action (based on both race and gender), and support for unequal distribution of resources based on group membership (Ho et al., 2015). SDO7 includes eight SDO-E items, such as: “We should not push for group equality,” (pro-trait) and “We should work to give all groups an equal chance to succeed” (con-trait). See Appendix F for the SDO7 scale.  
Social attitudes consistent with support for and willingness to comply with authority figures will be measured with the Attitudes Toward Authority Scale (ATA) (Varley, Votruba, & Shiota, in progress). The ATA is comprised of 16 items across four subscales measuring attitudes toward supporting and complying with authority figures: submission to formal authority, challenging authority, inherent superiority, and support for traditional norms. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with each item on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). The submission to formal authority subscale is 4 items that measure support for ingroup order, stability, and security, such as “It is important to follow the rules, even when you don’t want to.” The submission to formal authority subscale predicts an emphasis on patriotism and national security, including government surveillance. The challenging authority subscale is 4 items that measure support for individual rights as well as the good of the group, such as: “When making decisions, personal judgment is more important than obedience to traditions and rules.” The challenging authority subscale is not related to political orientation but predicted moral foundations of fairness and egalitarianism. The inherent superiority subscale is comprised of the four items that measure support for social dominance of one’s own group, such as: “Some groups inherently have authority over others.” The inherent superiority subscale predicts higher scores on SDO, values of power, and lower emphasis on the moral foundations of fairness. Finally, the support for the traditional norms subscale is comprised of 4 items that measure attitudes that support conformity and obedience of authority, such as: “People should be required to adhere to society’s norms.” The support for traditional norms subscale predicts an emphasis on religiosity, moral purity and socially conservative political attitudes.
Police identity and experience. Items will be included to examine and control for the influence of personal and vicarious experience with police officers. Participants will be asked yes (coded 1) or no (coded 0) questions about their connections with police officers and other law enforcement: “Are you currently a law enforcement officer?” “Do you have any family members or friends that are police officers or any type of law enforcement?” “Have you been arrested?” “Have you witnessed any family members or friends be arrested?” “Have you or your property ever been searched by the police?” and “Have you ever witnessed any family members or friends be searched or had their property searched by the police?” If the participant indicates that they are law enforcement officers, they will also be asked to indicate what type of law enforcement officer they are. Response options will include local police officer, state police officer, federal police officer/FBI agent, sheriff, corrections officer, and other with an open response option. 
	Participants will be asked to indicate how closely they identify with their family, neighborhood, community, state, nation, and the police officer on a series of items using five circles that overlap to varying degrees to measure identity fusion (Swann et al., 2009).
Procedural justice scale. Perceptions of procedural justice will be measured with an altered version of the Family Justice Inventory (Fondacaro et al., 2002), modified to be appropriate to police-civilian interactions. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with 36 items on a 5-point scale, 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). The Process Control, Voice, Neutrality, Dignity/Respect, Trust, and Global Fairness subscales will be included. A mean scale score will be calculated for each subscale. The Global Fairness subscale will serve as the dependent variable. 
Participants will indicate how they think of themselves in relation to the characters depicted in the vignette on a series of items using five circles that overlap to varying degrees to measure identity fusion (Swann et al., 2009).

Research hypotheses will be tested with ANCOVA, conducted in SPSS 26, and moderated-mediation analyses conducted with robust maximum likelihood estimation in MPlus 8.4 (Muthen & Muthen, 2010). 
Data analyses will be conducted in three phases. First, participants will be matched based on demographic characteristics and attitudes toward the police using propensity score matching to correct for the quasi-experimental nature of the design (West et al., 2014; West, Cham, Thoemmes, Renneberg, Schultze, & Weiler, 2014). Items will be aggregated and averaged where appropriate to create scale scores. Second, preliminary analyses will be conducted and descriptive statistics will be obtained to determine whether the data meet the basic assumptions of SEM. We expect to find a significant 2 x 2 interaction between vignette condition and sample for most of the subscales (voice, neutrality, trust, respect, global fairness) of the adapted Family Justice Scale such that the mean difference between the procedural justice and no procedural justice conditions will be greater for police officer participants than civilian participants, consistent with our previous findings for voice behavior (Hazen & Brank, 2020). When evaluating a police-civilian interaction as an observer, police officers will be more sensitive to the differences in the conditions because of their training and experience with police-civilian interactions (Hazen & Brank, 2020; Johnson et al., 2018) and because they identify with the police officer in the interaction (Oliviera & Murphy, 2016). Further, experience and feelings toward civilians will be added as covariates in an ANCOVA.
Finally, the mediation analyses will be used with bootstrapping (Shrout & Bolger, 2002) to test the modeled indirect effects of voice condition on evaluations of fairness through perceptions of voice, neutrality, trust, and respect. Additionally, the moderating effect of self-reported group identity and intergroup emotions will be examined. The bootstrap approach maximizes statistical power through resampling while minimizing the risk of Type 1 errors and creates confidence intervals (CI’s) through empirical approximation of sampling distributions of indirect effects. Nonparametric resampling methods (bias-correct bootstrap) with 5000 samples drawn to derive the 95% CI’s will be used for the modeled indirect effect of the procedural justice and outcome conditions on global fairness. 
Next, moderated-mediation analyses will test the relations among the components of procedural justice to understand whether police and civilians evaluate global fairness through the same mechanisms. Multiple group analysis will be conducted to examine whether the indirect effects and conditional indirect effects vary across police officers and civilians. The models will be over-identified; therefore, chi-square difference statistics will be relied on to determine if the models allowed to vary by group are significantly different from the model in which the paths were not allowed to vary across groups (Burnham & Anderson, 2004). Finally, the presence and magnitude of the indirect effects and conditional indirect effects will be compared across the groups. We hypothesize that the relation between procedural justice condition and evaluations of global fairness would be mediated in a serial, parallel mediation through evaluations of voice, neutrality, trust, and respect. Further, we expect to find that the relation between the procedural justice condition and each modified Family Justice Scale subscale will be moderated by the sample, consistent with previous findings for voice behavior (Hazen & Brank, 2020). The effects will be stronger for police officers than for civilians, replicating the interaction effects described above. This moderation would reveal that police officers interpret the components of procedural justice in police-civilian interactions differently than civilians and provide insight into which components should be examined further to better understand gaps between police officer and civilian interpretations of police-civilian interactions. Additionally, we hypothesize that the extent of identity fusion with the police will moderate the effect of the sample on the effect of the procedural justice condition. We expect that the effect of the sample will be stronger for those who identify more closely with the police than with their neighborhood or family (Oliviera & Murphy, 2016).

Attitudes toward police. Perceptions of police legitimacy and institutional trust will be measured with the Attitudes Toward Police Legitimacy Scale (APLS; Reynolds, Estrada-Reynolds, & Nunez, 2018) to control for pre-existing attitudes toward the police. The APLS has been found to be a reliable 34-item, single factor scale that measures perceptions of bias (3 items), quality of interpersonal treatment (4 items), trustworthiness (7 items), motivation (5 items), organizational integrity (4 items), being a member of the community (6 items), and normative alignment (4 items) of civilian respondents (Reynolds et al.). Responses will be rated on a 7-point Likert-type agreement scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree), with higher scores indicating more positive attitudes toward police. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with statements such as, “Police officers usually make fair decisions when enforcing laws,” and “Police officers are held to higher standards than regular citizens.”
The Allophilia scale (Alfieri & Marta, 2011; Pittinsky, Rosenthal, & Montoya, 2011) will measure feelings toward police and will be adapted from intergroup bias literature that have been found to be predictive of prejudice and discrimination. Emotions toward the police officers and civilians will be measured with the general dimension scales of the Positive and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS-X) (Watson & Clark, 1999). The two general dimensions scales measure negative affect (e.g., afraid, scared, hostile) and positive affect (e.g., active, alert, excited, proud) with 10 emotions per subscale. Participants will rate the extent to which they felt each emotion when they considered being involved in an involuntary traffic stop (e.g., being stopped by a police officer for speeding, stopping a civilian for speeding) on a 5-point rating-scales (1 = very slightly or not at all; 5 = extremely).
Social dominance orientation (SDO) scale (SDO7) (Ho et al., 2015; Pratto et al., 1994) measures support for inequality between social groups, but not ingroup dominance over outgroups. Participants indicate the extent to which they support 16 items on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly oppose, 7 = strongly favor). SDO7 conceptualizes SDO as comprised of two subdimensions, with half the items on each subscale framed in the positive (pro-traits) and half in the negative (con-traits): the dominance (SDO-D) subdimension and the egalitarianism (SDO-E) subdimension. Con-traits are reversed coded to calculate mean subscale scores for each dimension, with higher scores meaning the participants are more in favor of group dominance. 
SDO-D represents a preference for group-based hierarchies that are created and maintained through active suppression of the subordinate group. SDO-D predicts overt and active efforts by the superordinate group to obtain and maintain dominance, including old-fashioned racism, support for immigrant persecution, support of the death penalty, and support for militarism (Ho et al., 2015). SDO7 includes eight SDO-D items, such as: “Some groups of people must be kept in their place” (pro-trait) and “Groups at the bottom are just as deserving as groups at the top” (con-trait). SDO-E represents opposition to equality between groups through a network of hierarchy-enhancing policies and beliefs. SDO-E predicts system justification, opposition to affirmative action (based on both race and gender), and support for unequal distribution of resources based on group membership (Ho et al., 2015). SDO7 includes eight SDO-E items, such as: “We should not push for group equality,” (pro-trait) and “We should work to give all groups an equal chance to succeed” (con-trait). See Appendix F for the SDO7 scale.  
Social attitudes consistent with support for and willingness to comply with authority figures will be measured with the Attitudes Toward Authority Scale (ATA) (Varley, Votruba, & Shiota, in progress). The ATA is comprised of 16 items across four subscales measuring attitudes toward supporting and complying with authority figures: submission to formal authority, challenging authority, inherent superiority, and support for traditional norms. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with each item on a 7-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). The submission to formal authority subscale is 4 items that measure support for ingroup order, stability, and security, such as “It is important to follow the rules, even when you don’t want to.” The submission to formal authority subscale predicts an emphasis on patriotism and national security, including government surveillance. The challenging authority subscale is 4 items that measure support for individual rights as well as the good of the group, such as: “When making decisions, personal judgment is more important than obedience to traditions and rules.” The challenging authority subscale is not related to political orientation but predicted moral foundations of fairness and egalitarianism. The inherent superiority subscale is comprised of the four items that measure support for social dominance of one’s own group, such as: “Some groups inherently have authority over others.” The inherent superiority subscale predicts higher scores on SDO, values of power, and lower emphasis on the moral foundations of fairness. Finally, the support for the traditional norms subscale is comprised of 4 items that measure attitudes that support conformity and obedience of authority, such as: “People should be required to adhere to society’s norms.” The support for traditional norms subscale predicts an emphasis on religiosity, moral purity and socially conservative political attitudes.
Police identity and experience. Items will be included to examine and control for the influence of personal and vicarious experience with police officers. Participants will be asked yes (coded 1) or no (coded 0) questions about their connections with police officers and other law enforcement: “Are you currently a law enforcement officer?” “Do you have any family members or friends that are police officers or any type of law enforcement?” “Have you been arrested?” “Have you witnessed any family members or friends be arrested?” “Have you or your property ever been searched by the police?” and “Have you ever witnessed any family members or friends be searched or had their property searched by the police?” If the participant indicates that they are law enforcement officers, they will also be asked to indicate what type of law enforcement officer they are. Response options will include local police officer, state police officer, federal police officer/FBI agent, sheriff, corrections officer, and other with an open response option. 
	Participants will be asked to indicate how closely they identify with their family, neighborhood, community, state, nation, and the police officer on a series of items using five circles that overlap to varying degrees to measure identity fusion (Swann et al., 2009).
Procedural justice scale. Perceptions of procedural justice will be measured with an altered version of the Family Justice Inventory (Fondacaro et al., 2002), modified to be appropriate to police-civilian interactions. Participants will be asked to rate their agreement with 36 items on a 5-point scale, 1 (strongly disagree) to 5 (strongly agree). The Process Control, Voice, Neutrality, Dignity/Respect, Trust, and Global Fairness subscales will be included. A mean scale score will be calculated for each subscale. The Global Fairness subscale will serve as the dependent variable. 
Participants will indicate how they think of themselves in relation to the characters depicted in the vignette on a series of items using five circles that overlap to varying degrees to measure identity fusion (Swann et al., 2009).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Research hypotheses will be tested with ANCOVA, conducted in SPSS 26, and moderated-mediation analyses conducted with robust maximum likelihood estimation in MPlus 8.4 (Muthen & Muthen, 2010). 
Data analyses will be conducted in three phases. First, participants will be matched based on demographic characteristics and attitudes toward the police using propensity score matching to correct for the quasi-experimental nature of the design (West et al., 2014; West, Cham, Thoemmes, Renneberg, Schultze, & Weiler, 2014). Items will be aggregated and averaged where appropriate to create scale scores. Second, preliminary analyses will be conducted and descriptive statistics will be obtained to determine whether the data meet the basic assumptions of SEM. We expect to find a significant 2 x 2 interaction between vignette condition and sample for most of the subscales (voice, neutrality, trust, respect, global fairness) of the adapted Family Justice Scale such that the mean difference between the procedural justice and no procedural justice conditions will be greater for police officer participants than civilian participants, consistent with our previous findings for voice behavior (Hazen & Brank, 2020). When evaluating a police-civilian interaction as an observer, police officers will be more sensitive to the differences in the conditions because of their training and experience with police-civilian interactions (Hazen & Brank, 2020; Johnson et al., 2018) and because they identify with the police officer in the interaction (Oliviera & Murphy, 2016). Further, experience and feelings toward civilians will be added as covariates in an ANCOVA.
Finally, the mediation analyses will be used with bootstrapping (Shrout & Bolger, 2002) to test the modeled indirect effects of voice condition on evaluations of fairness through perceptions of voice, neutrality, trust, and respect. Additionally, the moderating effect of self-reported group identity and intergroup emotions will be examined. The bootstrap approach maximizes statistical power through resampling while minimizing the risk of Type 1 errors and creates confidence intervals (CI’s) through empirical approximation of sampling distributions of indirect effects. Nonparametric resampling methods (bias-correct bootstrap) with 5000 samples drawn to derive the 95% CI’s will be used for the modeled indirect effect of the procedural justice and outcome conditions on global fairness. 
Next, moderated-mediation analyses will test the relations among the components of procedural justice to understand whether police and civilians evaluate global fairness through the same mechanisms. Multiple group analysis will be conducted to examine whether the indirect effects and conditional indirect effects vary across police officers and civilians. The models will be over-identified; therefore, chi-square difference statistics will be relied on to determine if the models allowed to vary by group are significantly different from the model in which the paths were not allowed to vary across groups (Burnham & Anderson, 2004). Finally, the presence and magnitude of the indirect effects and conditional indirect effects will be compared across the groups. We hypothesize that the relation between procedural justice condition and evaluations of global fairness would be mediated in a serial, parallel mediation through evaluations of voice, neutrality, trust, and respect. Further, we expect to find that the relation between the procedural justice condition and each modified Family Justice Scale subscale will be moderated by the sample, consistent with previous findings for voice behavior (Hazen & Brank, 2020). The effects will be stronger for police officers than for civilians, replicating the interaction effects described above. This moderation would reveal that police officers interpret the components of procedural justice in police-civilian interactions differently than civilians and provide insight into which components should be examined further to better understand gaps between police officer and civilian interpretations of police-civilian interactions. Additionally, we hypothesize that the extent of identity fusion with the police will moderate the effect of the sample on the effect of the procedural justice condition. We expect that the effect of the sample will be stronger for those who identify more closely with the police than with their neighborhood or family (Oliviera & Murphy, 2016).

attributes.title: Supplemental materials for paper: Penerapan Metodologi SQUARE Sebagai Alat Analisa Keamanan Sistem Pada Aplikasi E-commerce (Prestashop)
attributes.description: Bisnis Online menjadi bisnis yang diburu banyak orang karena banyak kelebihan-kelebihan yang diperoleh melalui bisnis ini seperti modal yang tidak terlalu besar tetapi bisa menghasilkan uang yang besar, Salah satu bisnis Online yang sangat marak saat ini adalah perdagangan elektronik (E-commerce). PrestaShop adalah salah satu CMS Open source E-commerce yang bersifat gratis yang dapat digunakan untuk membuat sebuah website E-commerce. Seiring dengan meningkatnya pemanfaatan aplikasi CMS E-commerce yang bersifat Open Source, akan semakin banyak pihak-pihak yang berusaha mencari kelemahan-kelemahan yang ada. Celah keamanan ini dapat dijadikan sebuah bentuk serangan yang beraneka jenis dan tingkat kecangihannya. Dikarenakan aplikasi E-commerce yang digunakan yaitu Prestashop, berupa aplikasi Open Source maka keamanannya belum sepenuhnya terjamin. Oleh karena itu, perlu dilakukan penelitian untuk menganalisis kebutuhan keamanan informasi dengan menggunakan metodologi SQUARE, sehingga rekomendasi bisa diberikan sejak tahap awal sebelum aplikasi ini dipergunakan dan dipublish. Metodologi yang digunakan dalam penelitian ini adalah metodologi SQUARE yang terdiri dari sembilan langkah proses yang dikembangkan untuk membantu menganalisis kebutuhan keamanan aplikasi E-commerce. Hasil penelitian ini, dapat disimpulkan bahwa metodologi SQUARE sangat membantu dalam melakukan analisis kebutuhan keamanan sistem dalam pengembangan sistem berupa aplikasi E-commerce yang menggunakan CMS Prestashop.
