attributes.title: Cross-cultural differences in self-reported psychiatric traits
attributes.description:
Introduction
The field of psychological science regularly makes generalised claims about the prevalence of self-reported behavioural and psychiatric traits (and their relationships with biological and environmental factors), yet recruitment for studies investigating these claims is often limited to Western, Educated, Industrialised, Rich, and Democratic (WEIRD, e.g. American, European) populations.1,2 It is increasingly evident that psychological findings based on Western populations may not generalise to other cultures. Indeed, prior work3 has demonstrated that individuals from Asian or Black backgrounds, relative to those from White backgrounds, tend to score higher on self-reported measures of psychological traits, including those assessing symptoms of OCD and anxiety.

Cultural issues with online psychology research
There has been rapid expansion in recent years of large-scale data collection via the use of online recruitment platforms such as Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). These platforms provide a quick and efficient method for amassing a large participant pool for psychological research. However, this research often relies on the assumption that online participants are drawn from the same distribution of cultural backgrounds. To the contrary, recent work has shown that of active MTurk ‘workers’ at a given time, there are likely equal numbers based in the US and India. While workers based in India are typically as educated as those in the US, the different locations have esoteric features45 To get around these documented issues, many researchers restrict recruitment to local samples, which ultimately reinforces WEIRD norms.

Cultural issues with online psychiatry research
There has been less psychiatry-specific online research, but it is now growing in popularity. While prior studies have suggested that the proportion of individuals who score above clinically significant cut-off scores for e.g. obsessive-compulsive symptoms appears similar across MTurk and other community samples,6 our recent work7 found that nearly 50% of an MTurk sample scored above clinical cut-off for OCD. Exploratory analyses suggested that this effect was driven by a striking distinct distribution of scores between East Coast US workers and Indian/Sri Lankan/Pakistani workers (with bimodality seen in the West Coast US which has the highest proportion of Asian migrants in America8). Indeed, while online samples are thought to be more representative of the general population compared to college student samples (another common recruitment pool for psychological studies)9, collectively this evidence suggests that many online psychological studies using self-report measures may promote a biased or confounded interpretation of results. It is therefore important to gain a clearer understanding of the cultural differences which may underpin differences in response style among online participants in psychological research. In this study, we therefore test a simple prediction from our prior exploratory analyses: that there is a striking difference in OCD symptom scales across specific Western and Asian samples.

q2.value:
Study Objectives and Hypotheses
Objective: to elucidate cross-cultural differences in commonly used self-report trait and diagnostic measures. On the basis of prior work,1,3,7 this study aims to test the following predictions:

H1: Individuals living in UTC+5 and UTC+5:30 timezones (predominately South Asia, i.e. countries of the Indian sub-continent, including India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka) will score higher on commonly used measures of traits relating to mood and anxiety disorders (STAI, BDI, OCIR) compared to those living in a predominately WEIRD (Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, and Democratic) timezone, UTC-4 (i.e. East Coast America). 

H2: Demographics (sex, age, IQ) of participants will not differ, and scores will not differ on measures assessing symptoms of thought disorder (schizotypy).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Study Design
Population/convenience sample from individuals across the globe (recruited via MTurk). Data will be analysed using structural equation modelling, including linear regression models, in R. The primary dependent variables will be sum scores and subscales of included measures, and the independent variable will be geographic location/time-zone. 

The primary study site will be online, but co-ordinated from UCL Division of Psychology and Language Sciences, 26 Bedford Way, London WC1H 0AP. 

Participants and Recruitment 
Based on an effect size of cohen’s d=2.1 for the comparison between participants from East Coast Americas (UTC-4) vs. India + Sri Lanka (UTC+5:30) (figure 1 in attached document), we would require fewer than 10 participants per group to detect an effect of comparable size with 95% power. Halving this effect size to account for potentially inflated results would necessitate 23 participants from each time zone to detect an effect of d=1 with 95% power. To account for drop-off and non-compliance we will aim to recruit N=35 per group.

Participants will be recruited online using Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Participants will be reimbursed for their time and asked to contact the named investigator for further details of the study if they have any questions or concerns.  
Inclusion criteria
•	Aged between 18-60 years
•	Basic reading and comprehension ability of English 
•	Ability to give informed consent online
Exclusion criteria
•	In the opinion of the investigator, to be non-compliant with the study (i.e. not providing complete responses on online questionnaire measures or responding incorrectly to catch trials). 

Participants will be told that they have no obligation to complete the study even after they enrol and may withdraw at any point without providing an explanation.

Measures
1.	Age + gender
2.	Drugs + alcohol use
3.	Mental health history
4.	Schizotypal short scale 
5.	OCI-R (OCD)
6.	STAI (anxiety) 
7.	BDI (depression)
8.	Ravens progressive matrices (IQ)
9.	PHQ (physical health) 14 items 
10.	Catastrophising 
11.	COVID-19

Procedure
The study will be completed online using gorilla.sc. Prior to the experimental session participants will be told, via on-screen instructions, the details of the experiment and what they will have to do. 

The information sheet will explain in detail the nature of the experiment and the participant will be given the contact details of the investigator should they wish to ask questions. If the participant is happy to proceed and has read the information sheet they will sign a consent form electronically by ticking an on-screen box. 

After consent has been obtained, participants will complete the questionnaires (see measures), including answering questions about drug and alcohol use, age, IQ, and physical health which will be included as covariates in analyses. 

Upon satisfactory completion of the questionnaires, the participant will be remunerated for their participation. Each experimental session will last approximately 0.25 hours.

Measures
1.	Age + gender
2.	Drugs + alcohol use
3.	Mental health history
4.	Schizotypal short scale 
5.	OCI-R (OCD)
6.	STAI (anxiety)

Sum scores will be calculated for questionnaire measures where relevant.

We will employ a structural equation modelling framework (e.g. linear regression models with time zone as a predictor, questionnaire measures as outcome variables, controlling for gender, age and IQ) to investigate the effect of geographic time zone on sum scores of psychological trait measures, and use formal model comparison to determine the best-fitting model. Analyses will be conducted in R.

2.	Rad, M. S., Martingano, A. J. & Ginges, J. Toward a psychology of Homo sapiens : Making psychological science more representative of the human population. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 115, 11401–11405 (2018).
3.	Wu, K. D. & Wyman, S. V. Examination of racial differences in assessment of OCD symptoms and obsessive beliefs. Journal of Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders 10, 10–18 (2016).

5.	Litman, L., Robinson, J. & Rosenzweig, C. The relationship between motivation, monetary compensation, and data quality among US- and India-based workers on Mechanical Turk. Behav Res 47, 519–528 (2015).
6.	Arditte, K. A., Çek, D., Shaw, A. M. & Timpano, K. R. The importance of assessing clinical phenomena in Mechanical Turk research. Psychol Assess 28, 684–691 (2016).
7.	Daniel-Watanabe, L., McLaughlin, M., Gormley, S. & Robinson, O. J. Association between a directly translated cognitive measure of negative bias and self-reported psychiatric symptoms. Biological Psychiatry: Cognitive Neuroscience and Neuroimaging (2020) doi:10.1016/j.bpsc.2020.02.010.

registration_responses.q6.question:
Study Design
Population/convenience sample from individuals across the globe (recruited via MTurk). Data will be analysed using structural equation modelling, including linear regression models, in R. The primary dependent variables will be sum scores and subscales of included measures, and the independent variable will be geographic location/time-zone. 

The primary study site will be online, but co-ordinated from UCL Division of Psychology and Language Sciences, 26 Bedford Way, London WC1H 0AP. 

Participants and Recruitment 
Based on an effect size of cohen’s d=2.1 for the comparison between participants from East Coast Americas (UTC-4) vs. India + Sri Lanka (UTC+5:30) (figure 1 in attached document), we would require fewer than 10 participants per group to detect an effect of comparable size with 95% power. Halving this effect size to account for potentially inflated results would necessitate 23 participants from each time zone to detect an effect of d=1 with 95% power. To account for drop-off and non-compliance we will aim to recruit N=35 per group.

Participants will be recruited online using Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Participants will be reimbursed for their time and asked to contact the named investigator for further details of the study if they have any questions or concerns.  
Inclusion criteria
•	Aged between 18-60 years
•	Basic reading and comprehension ability of English 
•	Ability to give informed consent online
Exclusion criteria
•	In the opinion of the investigator, to be non-compliant with the study (i.e. not providing complete responses on online questionnaire measures or responding incorrectly to catch trials). 

Participants will be told that they have no obligation to complete the study even after they enrol and may withdraw at any point without providing an explanation.

Measures
1.	Age + gender
2.	Drugs + alcohol use
3.	Mental health history
4.	Schizotypal short scale 
5.	OCI-R (OCD)
6.	STAI (anxiety) 
7.	BDI (depression)
8.	Ravens progressive matrices (IQ)
9.	PHQ (physical health) 14 items 
10.	Catastrophising 
11.	COVID-19

Procedure
The study will be completed online using gorilla.sc. Prior to the experimental session participants will be told, via on-screen instructions, the details of the experiment and what they will have to do. 

The information sheet will explain in detail the nature of the experiment and the participant will be given the contact details of the investigator should they wish to ask questions. If the participant is happy to proceed and has read the information sheet they will sign a consent form electronically by ticking an on-screen box. 

After consent has been obtained, participants will complete the questionnaires (see measures), including answering questions about drug and alcohol use, age, IQ, and physical health which will be included as covariates in analyses. 

Upon satisfactory completion of the questionnaires, the participant will be remunerated for their participation. Each experimental session will last approximately 0.25 hours.

registration_responses.q16.question: Sum scores will be calculated for questionnaire measures where relevant.
registration_responses.q17.question: We will employ a structural equation modelling framework (e.g. linear regression models with time zone as a predictor, questionnaire measures as outcome variables, controlling for gender, age and IQ) to investigate the effect of geographic time zone on sum scores of psychological trait measures, and use formal model comparison to determine the best-fitting model. Analyses will be conducted in R.

attributes.title: Metformin on Pristane Induced Lupus
attributes.description: Evaluating the effect of oral and intraperitoneal metformin intervention on pristane induced lupus (female BALB/c mice). Measuring various pro/anti-inflammatory cytokines, FOXP3 mRNA levels and histopathological scoring.

summary.value: Providing data upon metformin efficacy on pristane induced lupus. Also metformin effect of FOXP3 mRNA expressions.
